institution_num.description: The name of the care_site as it appears in the source data
institution_num.notes: There are just the name fields, and then corresponding descriptive fields detailing the extended attributes of a given facility

private_clinic_institution_name.description: The name of the care_site as it appears in the source data
private_clinic_institution_name.notes: There are just the name fields, and then corresponding descriptive fields detailing the extended attributes of a given facility

admit_dt_date.description: Use this date to determine the start date of the condition
admit_dt_date.notes: The admission date is the start of the condition occurrence.

main_patient_service_desc.notes: The domain of the cost can be inferred from the main service or principal procedure.

main_patient_service_desc.description: Revenue codes are a method to charge for a class of procedures and conditions in the U.S. hospital system.

principle_procedure_desc.notes: The domain of the cost can be inferred from the main service or principal procedure.

encntr_num.notes: encntr_num is the encounter number. abstract_num is a unique ID for the abstract.

abstract_num.notes: encntr_num is the encounter number. abstract_num is a unique ID for the abstract.

cmg_intervention_ooh_count.notes: CMG (Case Mix Group) is the Canadian equivalent of DRG. This can be mapped to a standard concept.

cmg_intervention_ooh_count.description: The unique key given to a procedure record for a person. Refer to the ETL for how duplicate procedures during the same visit were handled.

cmg_trim_point.notes: CMG (Case Mix Group) is the Canadian equivalent of DRG. This can be mapped to a standard concept.

cmg_cmg_desc.description: Diagnosis Related Groups are US codes used to classify hospital cases into one of approximately 500 groups.
cmg_cmg_desc.notes: The source value for the Case Mix Group.

is_med_service_mhsu_at_admit.description: Revenue codes are a method to charge for a class of procedures and conditions in the U.S. hospital system.

payor_desc.description: Revenue codes are a method to charge for a class of procedures and conditions in the U.S. hospital system.

payor_desc.notes: These are relative cost weights, not actual monetary costs. They can be used to estimate costs.

cmg_resource_intensity_weight.notes: These are relative cost weights, not actual monetary costs. They can be used to estimate costs.

cacs_ambulatory_cost_weight.notes: These are relative cost weights, not actual monetary costs. They can be used to estimate costs.

autopsy.description: This is the provenance of the death record, i.e., where it came from. It is possible that an administrative claims database would source death information from a government file so do not assume the Death Type is the same as the Visit Type, etc.
autopsy.notes:
These fields indicate the circumstances and
location of death.

death_in_operating_room.description: This is the provenance of the death record, i.e., where it came from. It is possible that an administrative claims database would source death information from a government file so do not assume the Death Type is the same as the Visit Type, etc.
death_in_operating_room.notes:
These fields indicate the circumstances and
location of death.

death_in_operating_room.description: This field houses the verbatim value from the source data representing the procedure that occurred. For example, this could be an CPT4 or OPCS4 code.

disch_disp_dad_is_death.description: This is the provenance of the death record, i.e., where it came from. It is possible that an administrative claims database would source death information from a government file so do not assume the Death Type is the same as the Visit Type, etc.
disch_disp_dad_is_death.notes:
These fields indicate the circumstances and
location of death.

transfusion_given.description: This field houses the verbatim value from the source data representing the device exposure that occurred. For example, this could be an NDC or Gemscript code.
transfusion_given.notes: Also including any category that indicates the use of a device (hence we know there was device exposure)

medicine_reconciliation_desc.description: This field houses the verbatim value from the source data representing the drug route.

cacs_age_category.notes: You can technically calculate the age from any of these.

cmg_age_category_desc.notes: You can technically calculate the age from any of these.

phn_province_issuing.description: It is assumed that every person with a different unique identifier is in fact a different person and should be treated independently.
phn_province_issuing.notes: phn_province_issuing isn't the actual PHN, just the province it was issued in... closest we have for now but Jack did mention there's an actual PHN field for patient ID !

ed_unknown_time.description: Use this field to house the datetime that the procedure ended.

ed_unknown_time_phc.description: Use this field to house the datetime that the procedure ended.

cmg_mcc_desc.description: This field houses the verbatim value from the source data representing the procedure that occurred. For example, this could be an CPT4 or OPCS4 code.

entry_code_desc.description: Use this field to find the visit detail that occurred for the person prior to the given visit detail record. There could be a few days or a few years in between.
entry_code_desc.notes: Need to check description of this IHID field to see if it matches

institution_from_name.description: Use this field to determine where the patient was admitted from. This concept is part of the visit domain and can indicate if a patient was admitted to the hospital from a long-term care facility, for example.

institution_from_id.description: Use this field to determine where the patient was admitted from. This concept is part of the visit domain and can indicate if a patient was admitted to the hospital from a long-term care facility, for example.

institution_from_type_desc.description: Use this field to determine where the patient was admitted from. This concept is part of the visit domain and can indicate if a patient was admitted to the hospital from a long-term care facility, for example.

institution_to_id.description: Use this field to determine where the patient was discharged to after a visit. This concept is part of the visit domain and can indicate if a patient was transferred to another hospital or sent to a long-term care facility, for example.  It is assumed that a person is discharged to home therefore there is not a standard concept id for "home".  Use concept id = 0 when a person is discharged to home.

institution_to_name.description: Use this field to determine where the patient was discharged to after a visit. This concept is part of the visit domain and can indicate if a patient was transferred to another hospital or sent to a long-term care facility, for example.  It is assumed that a person is discharged to home therefore there is not a standard concept id for "home".  Use concept id = 0 when a person is discharged to home.

institution_to_type_desc.description: Use this field to determine where the patient was discharged to after a visit. This concept is part of the visit domain and can indicate if a patient was transferred to another hospital or sent to a long-term care facility, for example.  It is assumed that a person is discharged to home therefore there is not a standard concept id for "home".  Use concept id = 0 when a person is discharged to home.

cmg_grade_assignment.description: This field houses the verbatim value from the source data representing the kind of visit that took place (inpatient, outpatient, emergency, etc.)

cmg_inpt_riw_atyp_desc.description: This field houses the verbatim value from the source data representing the kind of visit that took place (inpatient, outpatient, emergency, etc.)

los.description: For inpatient visits, the start date is typically the admission date. For outpatient visits the start date and end date will be the same.

los_elapsed_time_hours.description: For inpatient visits, the start date is typically the admission date. For outpatient visits the start date and end date will be the same.

los_elapsed_time_minutes.description: For inpatient visits, the start date is typically the admission date. For outpatient visits the start date and end date will be the same.

facility_community_of_care_subgrp_desc_a.description: This is a high-level way of characterizing a Care Site. Typically, however, Care Sites can provide care in multiple settings (inpatient, outpatient, etc.) and this granularity should be reflected in the visit.

This is a high-level way of characterizing a Care Site. Typically, however, Care Sites can provide care in multiple settings (inpatient, outpatient, etc.) and this granularity should be reflected in the visit.

admit_dt_tm.notes: A more precise start time for the condition.

diagnosis_type_id.description: This field houses the verbatim value from the source data representing the condition status.
diagnosis_type_id.notes: The source value for the diagnosis status.

care_type.description: This field can be used to determine the provenance of the Condition record, as in whether the condition was from an EHR system, insurance claim, registry, or other sources.
care_type.notes: This indicates the type of care setting where the condition was recorded.

encntr_num.description: The visit during which the condition occurred.
encntr_num.notes: The primary identifier for the patient's visit.

encntr_num.description: The VISIT_DETAIL record during which the drug exposure occurred. For example, if the person was in the ICU at the time of the drug administration the VISIT_OCCURRENCE record would reflect the overall hospital stay and the VISIT_DETAIL record would reflect the ICU stay during the hospital visit.
Use this to identify unique interactions between a person and the health care system. This identifier links across the other CDM event tables to associate events with a visit.

disch_dt_date.description: The date the person was deceased.
disch_dt_date.notes: The discharge date/time should be used as the death date when disch_disp_dad_is_death is flagged.

disch_dt_tm.description: The date the person was deceased.
disch_dt_tm.notes: The discharge date/time should be used as the death date when disch_disp_dad_is_death is flagged.
The discharge date and time should be used as the death date and time when disch_disp_dad_is_death is flagged.

disch_dt_tm.description: If a Person is still an inpatient in the hospital at the time of the data extract and does not have a visit_end_datetime, then set the visit_end_datetime to the datetime of the data pull.

first_vte_prophylaxis_pathway_id.description: This field houses the verbatim value from the source data representing the device exposure that occurred. For example, this could be an NDC or Gemscript code.
first_vte_prophylaxis_pathway_id.notes: Also including any category that indicates the use of a device (hence we know there was device exposure)

first_vte_prophylaxis_pathway_initiated_.description: This field houses the verbatim value from the source data representing the device exposure that occurred. For example, this could be an NDC or Gemscript code.
first_vte_prophylaxis_pathway_initiated_.notes: Also including any category that indicates the use of a device (hence we know there was device exposure)

primary_health_plan_short_desc_src.description: This is the health benefit Plan of the Person as it appears in the source data.

gender_desc_at_admit.description: This field is used to store the biological sex of the person from the source data. It is not intended for use in standard analytics but for reference only.
gender_desc_at_admit.notes: NOTE!!! IHID stores the gender of the person at the census date. NOT the biological sex although their definitions may overlap in many cases

patient_postal_code_geographical_health_.description: The location refers to the physical address of the person. This field should capture the last known location of the person.
patient_postal_code_geographical_health_.notes: Six digit alphanumeric code assigned by Canada Post to identify patient's place of residence at time of discharge, and if that's not provided, then time of admit.

patient_postal_code_geographical_local_h.description: The location refers to the physical address of the person. This field should capture the last known location of the person.
patient_postal_code_geographical_local_h.notes: Six digit alphanumeric code assigned by Canada Post to identify patient's place of residence at time of discharge, and if that's not provided, then time of admit.

is_homeless.description: The location refers to the physical address of the person. This field should capture the last known location of the person.

provider_care_team_desc_src_at_admit.description: There will only be one provider per  **visit** record and the ETL document should clearly state how they were chosen (attending, admitting, etc.). This is a typical reason for leveraging the VISIT_DETAIL table as even though each VISIT_DETAIL record can only have one provider, there is no limit to the number of VISIT_DETAIL records that can be associated to a VISIT_OCCURRENCE record.

provider_care_team_desc_src_at_disch.description: There will only be one provider per  **visit** record and the ETL document should clearly state how they were chosen (attending, admitting, etc.). This is a typical reason for leveraging the VISIT_DETAIL table as even though each VISIT_DETAIL record can only have one provider, there is no limit to the number of VISIT_DETAIL records that can be associated to a VISIT_OCCURRENCE record.

surg_case_id.description: This is the concept representing the procedure source value and may not necessarily be standard. This field is discouraged from use in analysis because it is not required to contain Standard Concepts that are used across the OHDSI community, and should only be used when Standard Concepts do not adequately represent the source detail for the Procedure necessary for a given analytic use case. Consider using PROCEDURE_CONCEPT_ID instead to enable standardized analytics that can be consistent across the network.

surg_case_svc_id.description: This is the concept representing the procedure source value and may not necessarily be standard. This field is discouraged from use in analysis because it is not required to contain Standard Concepts that are used across the OHDSI community, and should only be used when Standard Concepts do not adequately represent the source detail for the Procedure necessary for a given analytic use case. Consider using PROCEDURE_CONCEPT_ID instead to enable standardized analytics that can be consistent across the network.

surg_case_svc_desc_src.description: This field houses the verbatim value from the source data representing the procedure that occurred. For example, this could be an CPT4 or OPCS4 code.

surg_operating_room_desc_src.description: This field provides information about the Care Site where the Visit Detail took place.

mrn.description: Medical Record Number as person identifier

special_care_unit_01_death_flag.description: This is the Standard Concept representing the Person's cause of death, if available.
special_care_unit_01_death_flag.notes: The cause of death can be sourced from the diagnosis codes, especially when diagnosis_type_id indicates it is a cause of death.

special_care_unit_02_death_flag.description: This is the Standard Concept representing the Person's cause of death, if available.
special_care_unit_02_death_flag.notes: The cause of death can be sourced from the diagnosis codes, especially when diagnosis_type_id indicates it is a cause of death.

special_care_unit_01_desc.description: This field provides information about the Care Site where the Visit Detail took place.

special_care_unit_02_desc.description: This field provides information about the Care Site where the Visit Detail took place.

special_care_unit_01_disch_dt_date.description: This the end date of the patient-provider interaction.  If a Person is still an inpatient in the hospital at the time of the data extract and does not have a visit_end_date, then set the visit_end_date to the date of the data pull.

special_care_unit_02_disch_dt_date.description: This the end date of the patient-provider interaction.  If a Person is still an inpatient in the hospital at the time of the data extract and does not have a visit_end_date, then set the visit_end_date to the date of the data pull.

special_care_unit_01_disch_dt_time.description: If a Person is still an inpatient in the hospital at the time of the data extract and does not have a visit_end_datetime, then set the visit_end_datetime to the datetime of the data pull.

special_care_unit_02_disch_dt_time.description: If a Person is still an inpatient in the hospital at the time of the data extract and does not have a visit_end_datetime, then set the visit_end_datetime to the datetime of the data pull.

intervention_desc.description: Use this to identify unique interactions between a person and the health care system. This identifier links across the other CDM event tables to associate events with a visit detail.
intervention_desc.notes: Listing all possible categories in both columns

intervention_order_number.description: Use this to identify unique interactions between a person and the health care system. This identifier links across the other CDM event tables to associate events with a visit detail.
intervention_order_number.notes: Listing all possible categories in both columns

intervention_cd.description: Use this to identify unique interactions between a person and the health care system. This identifier links across the other CDM event tables to associate events with a visit detail.

special_care_unit_01_admit_dt_date.description: This is the date of the start of the encounter. This may or may not be equal to the date of the Visit the Visit Detail is associated with.

special_care_unit_02_admit_dt_date.description: This is the date of the start of the encounter. This may or may not be equal to the date of the Visit the Visit Detail is associated with.
